text: UPDATED: JUN 13, 2017 Bomber from Sabatini?s. Cloudy yellow orange pour with a thin white head. Sour funk, wood, and Belgian yeast nose. Upon tasting I get sharp barnyard funk, soft woody notes, Belgian yeast, granny smith apple, and  chardonnay. Drinks like a sparkling white wine. Glad I picked this one up!

Bottle. Moderate grain and hay for the malt, moderate to heavy herbs and lemon for the hops, moderate to heavy musty basement for the yeast, with unripe pear, green wood and ginger in the background. Head is average sized, frothy turning wispy, white, with good lacing, and is mostly lasting. Color is murky medium amber. Flavor starts moderately acidic, then finishes lightly to moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, slick, with a lively carbonation, and a tart finish. Great Abbey Tripel, funky and sharp at one point, smooth and mellow at another.
Super tasty triple. Woody, citrus, bright hops, not super heavy or boozy, the Brett softens the Belgian yeast. Great. Thanks carl!
Poured from bottle batch 4 2014 nice golden color with a thin white head. Aromas of brett chardonnay barrel grapes and floral notes. Taste is nice floral notes grape oak dryness after time.

750 ml bottle thanks to TJ. Batch 4, 2014. Almost clear color, Aroma was of Belgian yeast, Brett, and a ton of oak. Flavor was light bretty dusty character, massive oak, mild Lemonaide. It turns into a funky oak and lingers. The balance of yeast and oak is nice.

750ml bottle 2012 vintage batch 2. Pours out a peach apricot color topped with a long lasting white head. Nose is big Brett notes the chardonnay barrel are big on this with a nice fresh oak and some fruit spice. Taste is more of the Brett forward oak barrel some spice and a great little sour tartness.

750 cc from Whole Foods and Smiths. Pours clear and highly carbonated golden with 2-finger, fluffy, white head. Nose is white wine grapes, oak, hops, tart citrus, yeasty funky. Great nose. Tastes like a semi-dry chardonnay with added hops, more oak, yeasty funkiness, and florals. Gets more dry as it finishes, remains as complex as hell, and tastes great. Methinks even white wine lovers would embrace this one enthusiastically.
Nice and tart aroma and palate. Light yellow color with cloudy appearance. Slightly oaked taste with bitter tart yeasts. Aroma is tart, musty, and lemon. Bottle

From a bomber poured in a snifter. Aroma is brett and a little bit of hop. Moderately lively body. A little bit of the chardonnay on the finish. Good tang from the brett. A little fruity and dry. Good Tripel but a little weird too.

Poured from a 750 ml batch #1 bottle. 
Aroma has some light malt and honey notes with hints of caramel. A light breadiness. Moderately strong fruit notes with stone fruit, pear, hints of tropical fruit, citrus and bananas. Medium light phenolic notes with pink peppercorn, lemongrass and coriander. Light oak notes. 
Pours a slightly hazy, bright gold with a medium large, thick, frothy white head that recedes steadily to the edges where a film lingers for quite some time. No lacing and moderately long legs. 
Overall, a decent beer but not particularly impressive. Everything was a bit muted (likely due to age).
Bright orange pour from 22oz bottle at home. White ring of head. Candy fruity aroma. Oak, fruits, and boozy. Peach, grapefruit and pear. Delicious

750ml bottle from Whole Foods. Slightly hazy yellowish gold color with a lasting white head. Aroma is nice bretty notes, lemon, herbal notes, barnyard, cat piss. The flavor is nicely brett/piss forward. Medium tart, citric, dry. Medium-plus body, high carbonation, good crispness. Nice.

Bottle, hazy light amber beer, big white white head. Aroma is funk, peach, kombucha. Taste is kombucha, peach, salt, lemon, lime. Palate is fairly light for a triple, carbonation moderate. Its been awhile since I first had this, and I think my palate has matured. I didnt really like it at first, now, its really interesting, and drinkable. A nice departure from a traditional triple.

750ml bottle at Sovereign in DC, pours a mostly clear gold with some fluffy, white head. Nose has musty white grape, some citrus pith, a little candy sugar, some straw, a little dusty couch, floral too. Flavor is very much a blend between a tripel and a saison, lemon and white grapefruit, straw and grass, some mild buttery oak, tart white grape. Finishes full bodied and a bit astringent.

Nice stuff. Manages the balance between tripel and bretta pretty competently mixed here. Light grapefruit bittet with some florals and tangerine. Pours golden amber without much head or lacing. Light tangy finish. Nice stuff. Bottle thanks to Iphonephan.
From a 75 cl bottle at The Sovereign in Georgetown DC. Pours a clear gold with an of white head. Aroma of tart grapes. Flavors coriander and oak. Smooth and delicisious.

Not a huge fan of the classic tripel style, so couldnt have been more excited to try Anchorages take on it. And WOW. Maybe one of the most complex beers Ive tried, but instead of being overwhelming it was just plain perfect. orth it). Aroma is Brett, citrus, funk and oak. Medium bodied and carbonation, a mild sweetness with some mango, apricots, oak and hop bitterness. Again, crazy complex, so really tough for this amateur to describe. All I can say is that this beer is a top 20 for me and my favorite from Anchorage, more interesting than both Love Buzz and Bitter Monk (which are amazing beers). Love this brewery.

Babyfood pineapple, lemon zest, brett, white grape, mild sharp cheese, oak nose. Wonderful! Cloudy amber, medium head, little retention. Peach, white grape overtones, sweet to dry. Medium body, warm, soft carbonation. The brett and hops make this an atypical tripel, which to me makes it better.

Pours a bright golden yellow color. Active carbonation throughout the session. Aromas of hops, fruit, and a little funky brett. Has a light fruity citrus taste, with some yeasty notes, a good hop flavor, and some winey notes in the tail.

Bottle shared at tasting. Pale golden, with a small white head. Smells sour and funky, of brett and oak, red grapes and barrel. Dry, a bit sour and bitter, grapefruit, bananas, yeast, honey and grapes. Medium body, bitter-sweet aftertaste.

Où, Quand, Comment : 
Bouteille, dégustée le 8/7/2013. 


Visuel :  
Couleur : orangée. 
Apparence : voilée. 


Arôme :  

Levures fruitées (agrumes, notes de fruits tropicaux), légèrement sauvages et épicées, léger de céréales, notes boisées vineuses. .


Goût :  
Entrée de bouche : Goût de levures fruitées (agrumes, traces de fruits tropicaux), épicées et légèrement sauvages. 
Un support de céréales et de miel est également présent avec une légère amertume de houblon herbeux, épicé et floral ainsi que des notes boisées asséchantes.


En bouche :  

Corps : moyen.
Effervescence : moyenne.
Texture : légèrement crémeuse.
Finale : plutôt longue, composée dune légère amertume de houblon floral, de levures épicées, sauvages et aux notes fruitées avec des notes boisées.

Slightly hazy golden color with white head. Aroma has some tart farmhouse funk, citrus zest. Taste is brett/yeast forward at first with some wine notes and finishes really fruity with melon notes. Medium body with high effervescence. Really well made, complex and tasty.
Bottle. Pours cloudy orange. Nose is orange and yeast. Very nice flavor of peach, orange and some funk. Great.

750ml bottle from Willeys Store, Vt. Shared with wife. Batch #4, July 2014. Aroma: white grapes, funky farmhouse, apples. App: hazy straw, even murky with loads of protein in suspension. Minimal white head. Taste and palate : medium body, vineous, strong alcohol, funky and light bitter finish. Overall: not bad not that much impressed. I find it too big. Maybe because how it was stored for more than a year on a shelves. Anyway still a good beer but not exceptional. It gets better as it gets warmer.

From tap. Hazy yellow golden color with off white head. Yeasty aroma, funky bretty, citrusy fruity, wood, dusty, spicy, wineous. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Medium Oily body with soft carbonation.

75cl bottle. Small white head atop hazy light amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, lemon, some cherry, light wood, funk. Taste is moderately sweet, Chardonnay, funk, some lemon, grapefruit. Medium body, low carbonation, light stickiness.
29 May 2015, bottle. pale yellow. Nose is funky, smarties candy. Ned body and mildly fizzy. Funky and smarties candy. Interesting. Not great.

This is a full frontal brett assault beer. You will get lots of brett in the aroma and the flavor and almost no character of the base beer. No nice estery fruit notes from the Tripel, no bready crackery malt aroma, no spiciness. All brett! If you love that - great! If you want to taste the base beer look elsewhere - this beer could have been any style and no one would know the difference.

This poured a slightly hazy golden color with a white head. Aroma was of Belgian yeast, Brett, doughy wheat and earthy hops. Flavor was light bretty dusty character, semi sweet candy sugar and.orangey lemony Peel. Nice
Bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow with small white head that lasts. The aroma is yeast, oak, brett. Thin mouth, funk, citrus, yeast, caramel malt, light sourness in the finish, good.

A fairly vibrant, softly hazed golden straw body momentarily presents a set of streamers beneath a mostly frothy half inch white head falling to a solid ring with a beach of frothy bubbles and meshed lines and dots of lace on one side of the snifter

Aromas and flavors of dank and lemony brett characteristics blanketing fairly lean bubblegum and banana sweetness laced with oak, apples, and white wine, soft white pepper, a nuance of darker spice conjures the traditional tripel banana bread profile emerging full of earthy mushroomy brett on an exceptionally silky smooth, creamy medium body offering rounded, yet lively, softly spritzy carbonation leading to a coating residual full of belgian / wild esters with nuances of barrel, a merry-go-round of banana bread, bubble gum, and lemon bars finishes out, another fun and very enjoyable Anchorage brew

750ml BATCH #4 JULY/2014 consumed a couple weeks after KC distribution served at 45º and warming into 14.7oz Stölzle Cognac snifter

Growler from Premier Gourmet. Pours a clearish golden yellow with modest-sized white head. Aroma is quite fruity and somewhat sour with tart apple, Brett, vinuous character, wheat and some sugar. Flavour is big sour apple/pear, some Brett funkiness, white wine barrel, a little candy sugar and grains. Average plus body. Nice.

Pours a golden color with a white head. White wine, brett, fruit, yeast, floral, hop, oak and malt aroma. Chardonnay, brett, yeast, pear, apple, lemon, floral, oak, hop, spice, funk, mild tart, honey, slight alcohol and malt flavors. Medium light body and average carbonation. Brett, fruit, yeast, and wine finish.
Bottle poured golden crystal clear with a quick diminishing head. Aroma Brett funk! Taste sweet hidden alcohol funky.

Pours hazy yellowish orange with a small white head. The aroma is heavy on the chardonnay aspects, some buttery oak, spicy hops, somewhat rich malt and light citrus. Fairly thick body, but there is a lot of fairly sharp frothy carbonation. The taste starts off with lots of crisp spiciness, mild brett funk, citric acid, pepper and some lemon character (sorachi ace?). The finish has some astringency, grapes, light oak and alcohol warmth. Pretty good, but doesnt resemble a triple much to me..... and thats fine by me.

(bottle - corked & caged 750 ml) Yellow/orange pour with a soapy white head. Slight funk in the beginning with some sweet malts and vanilla from the barrels. Flavor is lightly sweet at the start and throughout the middle into a dry and very lightly tart finish.

Bottle during bachelor party. Pours a cloudy brownish yellow. White head. Aromas of Brett, yeast, light citrus. Sour tart taste but the sweetness of the base is still there. Medium body. Medium high carbonation.
Bottle shared thanks to Dan. Poured cloudy yellow with white head. Sour funky brett aroma yeast. Light carb med bod. Dry yeast brett sour taste

Pours a cloudy honey orange with a small white head and good lacing. Dark specks visible in suspension. Aroma is slightly tart with some lemon citrus, light fruit, earthy funk and some spicy hop character. All of those notes follow through to the taste along with a lactic tartness, hints of vanilla, musty wood and a light acidic bite into a dry finish. Somewhat soft mouthfeel with a medium body and moderate/high carbonation. Doesn't fit neatly into the Tripel style guidelines but does its own thing, to good effect. Interesting depth of flavors that ultimately work.

2015 bottle. Foggy golden yellow with lots of particulates and a small white head. Aroma is sour and cheesy with sweet orange and grapefruit. Taste is the same with wet straw and some spice. Tangerine. Has a sharp, somewhat acidic, bitterness at the end. Wet and dry mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hazy orangeish brown color with bubbly white head. Smells citrus sour, barnyard funk, perm, apple, oak, cheese. Taste is a funky sour up front, acidic, a sweet honey hop bite, with a finish of oak, vanilla, caramel. Interesting take on a triple, maybe a little too schizophrenic. Transforms from sip to finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared. Pours hazy yellow with a small off white head. Aroma of Brett funk, malt, fruit, wood and light spice. Flavour is over moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. A fine example of how to mess around with a dull style and make it great!

Shared 750 ml. bottle poured to snifters, displaying a cloudy, orangey gold color, with a presentable layer of soft white head foam, and dots & dashes of lacing. The nose was yeasty funk, citrus as lemon & orange, pit fruit, light spice, and some oak, and vinous hints. The taste contributed a medium bitterness that was earthy, and a bit tannic in its astringency, decent carbonation, in a medium body, with a lightly tart, and rather dry finish. Well made, and a tasty addition to our session.

Bottle at home. Trying to get buzzed quick, so this should help. Pour is hazy honeycomb with a white head and decent lading. Yeasty, coriander, pineapple, lightly bretty, some mango, herbs, and white pepper in the aroma. Taste is heavy herbal, lemony, some pineappley brett notes, basil, lightly phenolic, vanilla and wood with a tangy finish. Full mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Has some Tripel characteristics, although I wouldnt call it a Tripel. Still tasty.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 4 Oct 2014) Hazy golden colour with frothy, white head. Fruity, malty taste with notes of peaches, tropical fruit, slightly earthy yeast and spicy hops.Fruity, malty taste with peaches, citrus, spicy yeast, grass and a slightly soapy, spicy bitterness in the finish. Almost full body, with a certain sweetness. Balanced bitterness. Spicy and complex, but interesting and quite tasty. Very nice.

Blonde voilé. Fine mousse blanche. Nez intense de brett. Fruit. Agrume. Orange. Fleur. Bois. Bouche: ronde. Entré sucré. Mielleuse. Levure sauvage/brett. Vanillé. Florale. Légèrement anisé. Wow. Minoume.

750ML C&C, split 2 ways @ 40F in stemware. Picked up at Hill Farmstead last week

A - Slightly cloudy muted orange with a 2 finger head. Cork didnt pop as expected. 

S - Arome is sweet with a funk and a lot of grape skin, tree fruit, some sweet orange. Very yeasty

T - Taste is nice though. much better than the nose. Really dense, fruit, peach and a lot of funk. Love the oak tannins and minor banana taste at the finish. Lots of sourdough and some lemon

M - Dense bottle conditioned mouthfeel. really nice

O - great beer.

750 mL bottle. Totally stoked when I saw this on the shelf at Binnys (Anchorage is crazy erratic in theyre distribution but always worth it). Pours an effervescent light orange-gold, smallish white head that quickly gives way to lots of bubbles. Nose is loaded with Bretty, barnyard funkiness, perfumy citrus, musty grapes, earthiness, i.e. a healthy does of the winey characteristics from the barrel. Mouth is medium bodied, spritely carbonated, light sweetness up front mingling with grapefruity bitterness, mildly tart, oaky, apricots, floral notes, über complex. A simply remarkable beer from the Land of the Midnight Sun that is perfect for a night in Chicago that more resembles the Arctic than the Midwest.
Bottle Batch #4: Poured a hazy orange, with a chalky white film of a head. Aroma is sweet musty fruit with spice. Taste is very strong alcohol laden fruit, peppery, oak, and slightly sweet finish.
gyllen klar med litt hvitt skum. Aroma av gjær syrlig. Smak gjær frukt. Co2 middels.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, white, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy medium yellow.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (herbs), moderately yeasty (cobwebs, barnyard, horseblanket), with notes of sour apple, lemon zest, band aid, pepper, gum.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety/watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Man, if only this didnt have Brett. As it is, its hard to call it a tripel, as its more of a generic strong wild ale...appley and band-aidy and a little sour. Very good for that sorta thing fer shure, but I was really hoping for a real tripel.

Bottle-conditioned 750ml. Oak-heavy aroma with strong brett yeast character of arm pit / sweat, lemon juice, chardonnay character is strong for me. Medium body, effervescent, medium sweetness, moderate bitterness, warming alcohol, strong tartness and high acidity. Creamy fine carbonation and good flavor balance, but more sour and tart and tannic / barrel-heavy than I prefer.
The smell is amazing. The taste is totally different, but even more amazing............
September 25, 2014. Bottle at SBWF. Pours cloudy golden with a minimal white head. Aroma is citrus, grain, funky and light sulphuric. Taste is light sweet, fruity and light tart.

Drucken på Stockholm Beer & Whiskey festival. Förstår att denna är hypad, fräsch men lite väl tunn tyvärr.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sample at SBWF 2014. Funky and hoppy smell. Hoppy taste with a funky barnyard flavour. Very nice!

"reminiscent of Temptation in so many ways...aroma, body and flavor all similar...and cheaper per ounce. I was getting to the point where (while all good) all the Anchorage bretty beers save for the dry-hopped Bitter Monk were too similar, but this one had enough body, fruityness and bubble-gummy goodness to shine through a bit, and the brett was done just right. Very nice!"

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2015 [5757-20130830] 750mL bottle. Sourdough yeast and mild barnyard aroma. Slightly hazy, light orange body with a quick foamy white head. Tart and sour doughy yeast flavour. Medium body is fairly sour. Good. (7/3/8-/4-/15) 3.7
(c/o wilco, w/ him, jercraigs)

[7159B-20150314] 1pt6floz bottle. Mild vegetable brett and cheesy yeast aroma. Clear, light orange body with a quick foamy off-white head. Bretty yeasty grains and fruity flavour. Medium body. Good. (8/3/8/3/15) 3.7
Overheard: "Smell this cork."

Bottled @ Zeebra #2. 15cl sample. The aroma has funky brett, citrus, some spicy tones, some tropical fruitiness. Bit hazy, yellow coloured beer with a white head. The taste is light bitter, has a slight hint of sourness, citrus, wine there, brett. Very Orval-ish. Good.
Hazy yellow with a pale head. Aroma is funky brett, citrus, peach. Medium bodied, citrusy on the palate, dry finish. Taste is citrus, brett, dry white wine.

Batch #2, bottled November 2012. 19 months old. Pours a cloudy light gold color with a large white head. Aromas of sweaty brett, orange peel and a whiff of white wine. Taste is dry and lightly bitter. Flavors of dried flowers, musty gym socks, sweat. Oranges, grapes and lemon. Still, all this comes together with a dry fruitiness that is exceptional. The finish is funky and off dry. A year and a half in the bottle has dried this one out and made into a world class beer. Excellent. Outstanding.

Reviewed from notes.
I poured this into a chalice.
The appearance was a golden yellow color with a decent looking transparency about it. Carbonation rose at a rapid pace filling a one finger white foamy head that fizzled quickly. There was no lacing whatsoever.
The smell was vinous and slightly spicy leading to some floraly grassiness.
The taste was vinous and floral with a decent backing from the citrus.
On the palate, it sat about a medium with a fairly sessionable sort of quality about it. The carbonation is very harsh - a bit overly done for a tripel.
Overall, uh, I would say this is an over rated Tripel as it more wine-like than beer-like if anything. Most likely wont seek this one out again.

Bottle from De Molen Beershop. Appearance: Gold, with a medium white head. Aroma: A lot of cheese when just poured into the glass, which diminishes quickly. lychees and other exotic fruits, lots of brett obviously. Palate: Medium body, leaves me with a dry mouth. Not sure what to think of it. Interesting experiment maybe, but not a winner.
Backnote, had this beer at the zeebra extreem beer festival 2014. fruity from the wine barrel, hoppy, and light sour from the brett

Bottled @ Zeebra #2, small sample. Hazy yellow color, medium frothy head. Aroma has funk, brett, citrus, slight spicy notes. Slight bitter, bit sweet, hint of sour. Quite dry in the finish. Lovely farmhouse tripel.

At Zeebra Beer Festival, THX to everybody sharing todays beers.
APPEARANCE: clouded blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: fruity, hoppy, nice.
TASTE: fruity, hoppy, nice.
Original tripel. Has a nice fresh sour touch due to the brett, The chardonnay aging gives the beer a smooth fruity edge. Good one.
Troebele citroengele kleur met een goede kraag. Ruikt fruitig, hop, honing, kruiden. Smaakt bitterzoet, fruitig en kruiden.

750ml bottle in a tulip. Pours hazy amber/copper with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of the Brett light funkiness, some light spices, pale and caramel malts, a little bit of light fruits, and some hints of oak. Flavor the same with a great blend of everything. Average texture. A really cool beer.

750 ml bottle

A rich tripel with a sour twist has aged well although in hindsight I would not have waited quite so long. I would be interested to see how a non-bretted version stacks up against other tripels as a benchmark.

Aroma / Appearance - The rich head is the color of aging newsprint. A light coppery base is bright underneath. Yeast, powdered sugar, candy canes, and fruit (specifically apples and lemons) sparkle like a sweet glaze.

Flavor / Palate - Yeast, powdered sugar, and lemon crisp tickle the tongue. A delayed blast of dry malts holds the profile together until the semisweet finish. Other than an odd taste of baby powder here or there this is a nice release. If not so spendy Id consider buying a few more Anchorage bottles.
750ml Flasche. Klare gelbe Farbe, schöne Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht malzig, fruchtig, holzig, hopfig, hefig. Geschmack süß, holzig, Citrus, Grapefruit, bitter im Abgang.

750 ml bottle; batch 2 Nov 2012. This one only spent one month in my garage, so its a bit strange that garage, so a bit strange that it sat on the store shelves for so long. The result is that the brett has had full time to develop -- not necessarily a good thing for this particular style. 

Pours into my Koningshoeven goblet a beautiful orange-gold with a small and short-lived white head, microbubbles rising from the sides early but settling down soon enough. The aroma is absolutely divine - 9 or maybe even 10 - with a lot going on. Sweet oranges and moscato over chardonnay oak. Hints of grapefruit, mango nectar. And then the funk and must: the one moldy clementine going soft in the bottom of the fruit bowl. The flavor doesnt quite rise to the high bar set by the aroma, but its still good. A bit more sour than the aroma initially suggests, canned pineapple juice, Sorachi ace lemon, brett coming on hard late with bitter walnut husk and covering over residual sweetness in each sip, aided and abetted by a modest hit of grapefruit pith hops. Fascinating to try a brett-driven tripel and remarkably good -- Anchorage doesnt disappoint -- for what can only be seen as a bold experiment. Yet a tripel may not be the best match for the strong brett profile, and in the end the lacks the alchemy that of the Anchorage white IPA.

Shared bomber with Sherm1016 and others at lake house NYE beer tasting; thanks! Pours a foggy yellow; little lacing. Definite sour / funky taste; grassy. Very enjoyable.

---Rated via iPad

[Bottle (750ml)] Pours a hazy gold with yellow hues and an average size long-lasting frothy off-white head. Lacing on the glass. Aroma is yeasty, bretty and semi-sweet along with some herbs, light grassy hops and a hint of wood -- theres tons going on here. Nice flavour of brett, spices, grassy hops, some grapes, a hint of wood and some light sour fruit. Alcohol is well hidden. Average to medium bodied. I loved it.
Bottled. Pours yellow with a small white head. Smells and tastes sour, creamy fruity hoppy.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden yellow-amber with a medium creamy white head that lasts a long time and leaves nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is oak, Brett, honey, citrus, a bit of white wine. Flavor is the same, medium sweet and lightly funky with a bit of finishing zesty bitterness. Oaky, vinous, and bretty, on top of a tripel base. Just a touch of astringence. Medium body, light carbonation. Boy those guys in Alaska are magicians with Brett!

Bottle. Colour...light yellow with a humongous white head. Nose... oaky grapes and yeast with peppery pineapple and kiwi. Palate...what a frothy monkey! After the froth recedes the tropical fruit takes over and pineapple takes the reins with mango and papaya as the wingmen. The styrian hops are most prevalent compared to the sorachis, but both are subtle compared to the other flavours going on. The Chardonnay finally makes its appearance towards the finish and the vinous aspect comes to light and casts an ethereal presence on the finish.

A: Mildly Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Lots of Lightm White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Yeast, Wheat, Lemons

T: Yeast, Lemons, Mild Belgian Sugars

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying, Mildly Yeasty

Overall, a really nice yeasty triple where the flavors arent overly sweet and the yeast definitely has a presence.

Apricotfarben, leicht trüb mit feiner Crema. Belgische Hefe, Chardonnay und Zitronensorbet im Aroma. Für 9% geradezu leichter und prickelnder Antrunk. Die Chardonnay Weinigkeit wird von der Hefe angenehm begleitet. Gegen Mitte kommt eine holzige Würzigkeit mit Vanille zum vorschein. Die Fruchtigkeit der Pampelmuse geht über in eine angenehme Bittere. Ein kuliviertes Tripel auf belgischen Pfaden, dass etwas sperrig ist, aber eine Menge an Aromen und Geschmack zu bieten hat. Die Anchorage Brewing Company ist einfach eine Bank für außergewöhnliches Bier!

Batch 1: Oct 2011

Pours light grain yellow with brilliant clarity and a solid quilt of bone whites. Smells really nice with lemons, pineapple, grain, clay, a little green olive juice. Flavor doesnt disappoint - nice bitterness, some grass, some almost teatree oil and leather with a bit of metal. Thin bodied with hi carb and a wet finish. Nice beer.

How: Bottle.
Where: NK Bar, Stockholm.
Appearance: Golden colour with a white head.
Aroma: Fruit, floral, citrus, hops.
Body: Medium body, low carbonation.
Flavour: Citrus, caramel, hops, brett.

Gelb, opaltrüb, schaumkrone verflüchtigt etwas schnell, fruchtig säuerlich im aroma, antrunk malzig, folgend von bittere und leichte säure, anhaltender nachklang

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Scarred Cloudy blonde, lovely thick but tight white head. Creamy, delayed key lime tang nose. Sumptuous creaminess under and over. Weird how this fits in, sweet and crystalline marshmallow dubbed with a quenching loop back to the bretty coil. Levee Breaking really freshment in a Tripel on the finish. Bang tidy. Bottle, Craft Beer Co N1 a year ago, 500th rate

Light golden in color... Aroma is light citrus, funk... Flavor is citrusy, sweet... Light sourness, slight funk... Great beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

C&C 750 mL bottle from Whole Foods Market, Paramus. Pours a hazy orange color with a medium sized creamy white head. Good head retention. Aroma of brett, citrus, candi sugar, cotton candy, plums, mild earth and vinous notes. The taste is dry malts, vinous notes, brett, stone fruits, citrus, cotton candy, herbal hops, breadiness, lightly tart finish. Medium bodied, high carbonation. Nice beer.

750 ml bottle shared with seb from winooski beverage. A: floral, with some lovely barn carachter, herbacy. woody App: clear pale with small white head. t/p: thin body with light acidic finish. o: superb. a fortunate random pick. will need to buy again.

2014-08-30. Lightly hazy bright yellow body with a nice foamy head. 3+ Aroma is quite bretty, lightly musty and funky throughout, whisper of fruit, ad lemon. Whisper of unused cat litter like must. 7+ Flavour is refreshingly sour up front, with a musty quality to it. There is a lemony quality to the hops that grows as it goes on, to its benefit. 750 ml bottle into chalice; Batch #1 bottled 10/2011. Pours hazy golden amber color with a 1 finger fairly dense white head with decent retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers. Aromas of big lemon zest, orange zest, pear, peach, pineapple, apple, pepper, clove, white wine, oak, herbal, floral, funk, and yeast earthiness. Incredible aromas with big complexity and balance of fruity/spicy yeast and wine barrel notes; with good strength. Taste of lemon zest, pear, peach, pineapple, apple, clove, pepper, oak, white wine, floral, herbal, grass, funk, and yeast earthiness. Slight earthy tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of light fruits, pineapple, peach, pepper, clove, oak, white wine, floral, herbal, grass, funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast flavors with well balanced wine barrel presence; and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a smooth, crisp, and fairly prickly mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is a fantastic Belgian Tripel with Brett. Big complexity and balance of all flavors; and very smooth and crisp to sip on. A highly enjoyable offering.

A steady pour into my Teku glass produces a two-finger thick, pale, off-white colored head. The beer is a straw color that shows a bright, though hazed, light yellow-gold hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells of lemon like hops up front backed by cracker like pale malt and a touch of toasted, woody oak. The nose is actually fairly light, compared to what I was expecting, the hop character is definitely the most noticeable note here. Soft notes of spicy, hot, higher alcohols, light medicinal and clove like phenols, and a soft pear / melon like fruitiness are just noticeable once I start to dig around a bit.

Effervescent and fairly light bodied, the beer has just a touch of viscosity to it, but is quite quaffable. The hop character adds a nice lemon like quality, a definite bitter bite, a sort of pine / herbal character, and perhaps a touch of hay / grassy character; this last is accentuated by the pale malt character that has a soft, chewy cracker like note to it as well. The Brettanomyces character is still fairly light here, it has an oral / nasal effect that contributes softly antiseptic phenolic notes, some light mustiness, and perhaps a hint of funky, musky character (though only just). The oak character plays a supporting role here, but once you start to notice it, the oak character is quite present; woody, spicy, alcohol accentuating, and some soft vanillin notes are all contributed by the wood.

Not bad, but the oak character makes it a touch sharp and not quite as balanced as it could be; A bit of age might help this, but then it would lose the nicely vibrant hop character too. With the Brettanomyces (assuming it wasnt filtered out), this beer could change quite a bit with age, and perhaps for the better.

Pours a hazy, pale golden orange color with a one finger frothy white head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Decent retention with streaks of soapy lacing left behind. 

The aroma of this beer is pretty complex with hints of earthy hops, sweet citrus, oak barrel and funky wild yeast notes bouncing off of each other. The barrel presence is prominent with toasted oak, vanilla, spice and white wine notes followed by vinous and tropical fruit, resinous pine and musty funk. As it warms, the wild yeast comes to the forefront with musty brett and a subtle lactic character that compliments the hop profile. The Chardonnay/white wine notes are also pretty strong with grape must and other light fruit notes. This slightly overpowers the hop profile but there are still hints of pine needle and tropical fruit. 

On the fuller end of medium bodied with soft carbonation and a prominent barrel presence that adds complexity without interfering with the hops and wild yeast notes. Some charred oak along with vanilla and buttery white wine flavor which is countered by a dry, bitter pine presence and a strong, musty brett character. The wild yeast provides some dry, earthy funk that compliments the resinous hop flavor and gives balance to the tropical and vinous fruit sweetness. Underneath the barrel and wild yeast, there are hints of citrus peel, apple, pear and alcohol but the high ABV is well masked making this complex beer pretty quaffable. There is a lot going on here but the wine barrel, earthy hops and funky yeast notes are almost perfectly balanced resulting in another excellent beer from this brewery.

Highly tropical, wild flowery, resinous, lilac scented ale... I cant find a better word than high-pitched to describe the aroma, explosive and going everywhere, but not doing too much of anything and thus maintaining a certain sense of balance, albeit one that can go overboard at any moment. Fairly strong white wine character, with buttery, vanilla and tart notions. Slightly vegetal (onion?). The palate is dry, a feeling perhaps diminished by the oily chardonnay and concealing its 9% ABV with an undeniable competence. If the large bubbles feel agressive enough initially,. they quickly settle down to a more diplomatic level. Leathery, coniferous, wild finish with plasticy and medicinal phenolic notes aplenty, but a certain charm in the sheer aromatic intensity. Difficult to be more original than Anchorage brews, but somehow, this brewer manages to make the most extravagant recipes balanced and drinkable, if a bit gimmicky.

750ml bottle, Batch #1 from October 2011.  I dont like many tripels, but I have a feeling Gabe Fletcher probably knocked this out of the park.  The pour yields an ultra-cloudy, glowing, dusky golden-amber body thats strewn with limitless pinpoint carbonation.  A tall and moderately dense head of steadfast, cream tinted foam leaves patchy flares of lacing all over the glass.  The nose is exceptional, showing a soft and fresh base of creamy, pale cereal thats about as well attenuated as a 9% beer can be.  Hops are complex and perfectly married to the malt base, showing lemon pith, sweet rind, and tropical pineapple.  Buggy, brett-laden wood imparts notes of dust, white pepper, and creamy Chardonnay.  Hot damn, this smells just about perfect.  Flavors are right in line, running the gamut from creamy pale malt to assertive, lemony, citrus-driven hops and dusty, peppery, fruit and brett-kissed wood.  The "lemon cream pie" bottle descriptor isnt far off, as the creaminess really moves to the forefront at points, but it ultimately finishes dry and dusty like a proper brett beer should.  Close your eyes and you get bold notes of creamy, oaky, Napa Chard. The palate is substantive, creamy (I feel like Im over using that word...but its quite applicable here), well carbonated, and drying on the finish.  Damn fine beer.  This is arguably the best tripel Ive had to date (edging out another Gabe Fletcher creation  Midnight Sun Jupiter).  Exceptional.

Nose holds amazing fruity brett funk, big sweet vinous oak and chardonnay notes, pineapple and nectarine, touches of lemon pepper and custard from the Sorachi Ace, notes of brine. Flavor is gorgeous; same nectar and tropical fruit, touches of dryness in both peppery yeast and brett, and some increased floral presence. Stunning palate; dries out at the finish, great medium carbonation. Awesome brew.

Hazy orange pour with a lasting frothy white head. Really delicious tropical and nectar fruit and earthy lemon cheesecloth in the nose lead to delicious lemon custard brett character, hints of booze, and eathy brett. Lactic acid character abounds. Medium body with awesome carbonation- a tad low- but really nice for the style. What an awesome brewery this is.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Served in a SAVOR glass.

Pours a good golden color with a nice, fluffy white head. Good rocky foam with nice retention and a good dose of lacing on the way down. The nose carries a strong Brett presence with some earthy funk to go along with some yeast spice and faint barrel notes.

The flavor is also pretty Brett heavy, but also has notes of oak, yeast spice, and a bit of hops. Medium body with spritzy carbonation and a dry finish. Earthy. Not quite as good as some of Anchorages other offerings, but still quite tasty.

Bought this beer for a tasting, but we never got around to opening it - do I save if for another tasting? - I ponder this for a bit - but, nah...its Easter so I guess I can open something special (ie. expensive) - sure, Im an atheist that hasnt believed in Jesus since the 7th grade, but fuck it - anyway, the beer pours a turbid gold with a fluffy, thick, lasting lace - nose is spicy and zesty hops, moderate chard character, some Brett notes of pineapple and herbal tones of chamomile, rose hips, along with some mango and tart apple - a really lovely aroma - moderate, mildly creamy carbonation - flavor is sweet up front, with some mango and pineapple - spicy hops and lightly peppery phenols rise up through the middle - strong chard notes rise and fall on the tail end, leaving behind a moderately dry finish swimming with complex notes of dry Brett earthiness, white pepper, sage, melon - a tad too much alcohol heat in the finish, but this is otherwise a very lovely beer - happy zombie Jesus day!

Batch 1 bottle to tulip. Pours hazy pale light amber gold with a soapy white head that settles to a wispy film and some lacing. Aroma is just like the rest of the Anchorage brews funky tart fruity scents with hints of wet corks. Taste starts with a solid bitterness and turns into subtle tartness and wood with plum skin and some sour grape and Brett and wine characteristics. Palate is medium and chalky with a musty drying finish. Seriously I could drink Anchorage beers all the time, but I would go broke!

750 ml corked and  caged bottle. Aroma is dusty old brett, apple, pineapple, Pours hazy yellow with a medium dissipating white head. Taste starts out sweet but quickly turns bitter and finishes bitter,dry and slightly tart. Carbonation is average, body is medium. Good, but its resemblance to authentic Belgian Tripels is pretty minimal.

25.4 oz bottle.  Misty yellow orange with white fluff.  Nose is green banana, lemon zest and toffee.  Creamy with a soft buzz.  Taste is lemon custard, banana, lemon juice and yeast.  Interesting but not inspiring.
#1416 Bottle; Nose is sweat, hay, decent urinal cakes, gun powder, feel is watery, carb is medium, taste is lady finger, some sour hay, decent brett, little barn yard, later sweet camomile

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2013 Bottle served in a tulip. Batch #1. Very hazy light orange with a medium sized top. Average retention and spotty-watery lace. Ultra bright fermentation based aroma of fruity yeast and brett that lets the imagination run wild. Add soft wood notes, cheese, and a hint of vanilla. Just gorgeous. The palate is yeasty and bitter dry. Light-medium body, light creamy texture, solid carbonation, and a light bitter, dry finish. Excellent! Revisited Batch #1 a year and a half later. It has changed, but its still amazing. The brett and cheese are there, but the vanilla is now coconut. The palate and finish have become quite tart. Developing perfectly. Kudos Anchorage.

Golden straw in color, hazy with a thin head.  Nice big Brett Aroma and flavors.  Light wine barrel flavor and aroma lingers.  This is a tasty tripel.  Very good beer.  Anchorage brewing is hitting the mark with there brews.

750 ml. Hazy, golden body. Frothy, pillowy white head. Looks like a heffe. Aroma of clove, brett, toasted grain, lacquer. Hints of lemon, earthiness, barnyard funk. The flavor is moderately sweet. lightly bitter and lightly tart. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet, moderately bitter and lightly to moderately tart. Medium body, watery texture turning velvety and lively carbonation. What could be an overly sweet American tripel is tamed by tartness, funky brett characteristics and bitterness. An interesting take on a tripel. Nicely done.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2012 This is the fourth beer Ive now had from this brewer and I continue to be impressed.  This one pours a golden-orange color with a thick lasting foam on top.  The aroma is bretty and fruity; oranges, and lemons coming to mind.  Theres a hay-like horsey scent that is joined by heavy notes of white wine and oak.  The alcohol in this isnt completely hidden but even at 9% the body is velvety and silky smooth.  Oak and a white wine character mix with tropical fruit flavors of banana and mango.  Lots of brett here; funky, dry, and slightly tart.  Excellent stuff.  It doesnt necessarily come across being as complex as some of their others, say Bitter Monk IPA.  Im also starting to pick up a common denominator with most of their offerings, but if its going to be this good, Im not sure I care.  At this point, Ill be surprised when something from them is not at, or near world class.
From a bottle poured a straw color with a fair amount of head.  Light malty flavor with a light sour flavor and finish.

Bottle in Hotel Room, Brooklyn. Clear yellow/golden - white head. Nice bretty, white wine note, sweet grapes, spicy notes, light malty, fruity, oakey tartness, light flowery, lovely high bretty. High drinkbility.

750 ml bottle.  Hazy yellow- orange pour with small white head.  Aroma of brett, lemons, and juicy fruit gum.  Some earthy and hay notes.  Big brett.  Flavor is mildly sweet, dry brett, zesty yeast notes.  White oak.  Vanilla, honey.  Mild lemon, hay, wet wood and wool.  The brett gives a nice balance to the typical sweetness of a tripel.  Nice, slick mouthfeel.   Overall, one of the better tripels Ive ever had.

I have absolutely loved every anchorage beer I have had an this was no exception. It pours cloudy gold with minimal lacing. The aroma is bretty for that funkiness and sour with notes of lemon and oak. The flavor is incredibly complex. It starts off with a tart/sour taste followed by Belgian spiciness and some bretty barn notes. I also taste some lemon and grape notes. So much going on. Great mouthfeel and nice spicy/tart finish.

Appearance was cloudy golden with 1 finger white creamy lasting head, slight lacing. Aromas was butterscotch, oak, cardonnay,barnyard funk with the bretts creating loads of orange, lemons, sour notes. Taste was brett and cardonnay upfronts with citrusy earthy woody warmth. Malts where sweet sublime and hops where slight pine. Palate was unique smooth with creamy carbonation and long bretty sour dryish finish. New favorite American trippel...

Très pale, trouble, belle effervescence. En bouche cest un vrai terrain de combat où le Brett et le Sorachi Ace saffronte sous loeil attentif de mon palais. Le côté beurre du houblon japonais est bien incrusté et complémente magnifiquement labrasivité du Brett. Je suis encore assomé par la conception sans bavure de cette bête.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2012 Pours cloudy bright lemon rind yellow with two fingers of dense sticky white head.  Awesome nose, bursting with raw fruit juices, pineapple and pink grapefruit most notably.  Lots of crushed white pepper and fresh hibiscus, hints of alcohol. Dry and zesty with lots of pineapple and sage.   Very zesty/spicy. Light body.

Hazy yellow pout and soapy white head. Nose is lemons, orange, lime peel, funk, citric acid, basement. Flavor I phenolic spices, lemony hops, basement Brett funk, various other phenolic spices. Light and crisp and dry on the palate. Drinkable and great.
Cloudy golden pour with a nice white head. Smells of citrus, funk and wine. Taste is amazing with the citrus and funk working well together. Wine like flavors are present as well. Very enjoyable!

bottle poured a dark golden in color with a one finger fluffy white head. aroma has punchy chardonnay, oak, brett, sweet fruit, peach skin, and a hit of citrus. wow this is bright and has a perfect sweetness. mouth feel is light and there is big high side carbonation. flavor has lots of chardonnay barrel, oak, white grapes, and grape sweetness. brett is pronounced and gives off some funk mixing well with the fruit and citrus. it is such a bright beer with the brett drying it out cutting the edge back softening it a bit all around. I have been so impressed with there beers and this is no exception!

Pours ve ry cloudy gold with nice fluffy head and decent lacing.  Nice aromas of citrus and yeast.  Tastes of plenty of Brett, pepper, orange lemon citrus, tart, with light alcohol.  Very fun brew for 70 degree March night in NYC

Bottle from Whole Foods Bowery shared at James get-together. Pours medium yellow with white head. A little funky/zesty, but overall a more muted version of the brettbombs Ive come to expect from Anchorage. Not incredibly complex or interesting in comparison to those, but this was still pretty good. Crisp and refreshing.
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2012 Bottle with friends. Pours a hazy body with white lacing. Aroma is lemon, mint and funk. Mouthfeel is nice with notes of tart, spice, funk, and lemon.
Bottle. Pours a hazy amber with nice head. Smell is strangely minty. Flavor is dry, tart, and nice.

fun funky aroma with lemon and horses and a bit of caramel and oak. flavor is great and fruity, with more body and deeper flavor than a classic tripel with a nice blend of tart, sweet, and bitter. interesting texture, soft but with fine bubbles, maybe meringue like someone else said. the brett is very apparent here, and theres a good bitterness throughout, like lime peel. alcohol gives a nice warmth. some grassiness, from hops maybe, also slight soap.
Wow! Unique in every way. Cloudy golden body with an excellent retaining white head. This smells like white burgundy and has a lemon curd palate and meringue mouthfeel. Dogfish influence is evident.

Bottle from Jazzz.  Pours a bright straw color with a frothy white head that leaves plenty of lacing.  Smells of Chardonnay, green strawberries, and canned peaches.  Tastes of pilsner malt, hops, dried tropical fruit, and finishes with a bit of phenol.  A solid beer for the style.

Delicious beer sampled in LV!  Oh, the Brett!  Sour, funky, earthy brew with lemongrass, hay, and citrus.  Flavor is similar...lots of grapefruit pith and leafy hops.  Tart and astringent.  Lots of lime, orange peel, and lemon...yum!

Bottle, thanks Lalo.  $16.99 @ Carrboro Beverage Co. Big cloudy orange golden with a thick pillowy white head.  Nose is very dry with loads of pineapple brett, some lemon, light grapefruit.  Flavor is similar, heavy brett influence, fairly dry, little bits of sweetness to balance things out.  Very little spice if any at all.  Can taste the booze a bit after swallowed.  This beer is very good.  My only complaint with this beer, the saison, and the double ipa is that they all kind of taste the same.   The saison is definitely more fruity than the other two but theyre wine barrel aged with brett.  I love sour funky beers so Im not going to complain too much.   Just wish it was a little more affordable.

Tasted at the Triple Rock Sour and Barrel Aged Fest on 2/12/2011. This Abbey Tripel pours a medium orange gold color from a 750ml bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity. apricots, peaches and bretty. A medium bodied tripel. The malts are fruity and sweet, apricot and peaches. The hops are herbal and citrusy/lemony. Lively carbonation. Some yeast and funk behind the sweetness. Somewhat dry at the finish. Very drinkable, tripel. Love the sorachi ace and the brett. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean, crisp and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet with a touch of brett.
Bottle. Light tan color, lacing. Tastes like an abey triple...and its very good... was hoping for some more Brett and to be a little more sour. Pretty good though

Bottle.  Pours a very hazy gold with a large white head. Brett on the nose, sweet and funky, dry earthy brett.  Medium bodied, sweet and bretty initially.  Warms quickly with some big alcohol, a touch biting at times, but full of clean light malt.  Sweet musk, loads of brett, but never overpowering.  Finishes with some light cereal notes, a touch of warming alcohol, and more delicious brett. Another amazing beer from Anchorage.

Thanks to dcschiller! Pours a nice hazy gold and big whitish head.  Aroma is bretty, yeasty, fruit, light spice.  Great flavor.  Good hit of brett, the chardonnay barrels add a nice touch, really a cool beer!

750ml bottle from total wine las vegas.  Pours a hazy golden color with white head.  Aroma is earthy, some fruit. Sweet with more earthiness and some bitterness. Lighter bodied and dry finish. Good stuff.
bottle sample at Tripel Rocks Sour Fest. bretty bandaid aroma with dill Sorachi ace notes. Herbal funkiness, unique bitterness. Solid brett character. very unique & tasty tripel

Bottle from 12many. I just now realized this was a collaboration with DFH.  My first Anchorage Brewing beer.  Theres alot going on in this beer but it still remains balanced and drinkable.  Hoppy, funky, and moderately sweet.  The Brett, oak, and Sorachi Ace come together nicely to form a unique and interesting take on a Tripel. Pretty good shit.

Bottle. Pale golden beer with a whitish head. Tart, bretty aroma with earthiness. Brett and malt flavor with light tartness and light spice. Medium bodied. Malt and brett lingers with light tartness and earth.

Bottle. Pour is gold with a nice tan head, good retention/lace. Aroma of melon, floral hops, orange peel, light barrel, white wine, dust. Taste is lavender (?), orange peel, lemon, vanilla, white wine, funk. Palate is soft, average carbonation, dry finish.

750mL bottle purchased at KNB Wine Cellars for $14.99. Didnt realize they used Sorachi in this--its been a while since Id had a beer with the hop, so maybe I wont be sick of it any more.  Slightly hazy light golden with a 1 1/2 finger creamy white head, pretty good retention.  Floral orange citrus in the nose with some light lemon Sorachi following behind, yeasty and peppery with some (fresh) leather, rounded out by a bit of white wine and oak.  Flavor continues to be fairly floral with some fruity brett, overall pretty dry, light spicy alcohol in the finish, bitterness peaking at a 3-4, lightly buttery with the brett. Burps saltine crackers. Light to moderate creamy carbonation with a medium body.  Hooray for an American brewer not making a ridiculously sweet and estery Belgian beer. And, the Sorachi Ace was just fine.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle from Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours cloudy golden with an attractive off-white head and a fruity aroma. There is a slightly sour pale malt flavor that turns bitter at the finish. There is an interesing hop profile and a noticeable yeast presence. Quite complex for a Tripel and very tasty.
Only one sample of this one during EBF night of the barrels so consider this a short and sweet rating. Lots of brett, tart, citrus (mostly lemon); but an odd finish that left me a bit disappointed.

750ml bottle. Rating #7. Murky and thick dark yellow/orange pour with a sticky white head. Light funk and a little fruity sweetness and a touch of orange peel. Taste is citrusy, more orange peel and a little more sweetness and acidic. Pretty tasty. (2157)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 750mL bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe.  The aroma on this is full of Brett.  Barnyardy funk, with some lemony citrus tartness present, too.  I also detect some hints of celery seed as well.  The aroma on this is pretty good, but judging from it, I would be more inclined to call this a sour/wild ale than a tripel.  Mildly hazy golden blonde body with a smallish, spritzy off-yellow head, which is fairly strong and persistent.  Really swell legging and lacing.  The start is a bit acetic, astringent, with Barnyardy Brett tartness.  This does not dominate, though.  The base beer really comes through in the end, with a sticky, almost sugary honey-like flavor present.  Chewy mouthfeel later on, which balances the Brett tartness.  This is well-balanced, and more enjoyable than I expected.  After tasting this, I would call this a tripel after all.

Bottle @ The BeerMongers... A cloudy, pale, vibrant yellow with a frothy head that retained throughout the whole glass.  Nice lacing.  Nose had some brett funk with a musky yeast earthiness.  Flavor wise some oak and wine-like characters that contributed a mild booziness.  Vanilla, sweet grains, malt sweetness, and a touch of hop bitterness.  Some botanicals and an herbal earthiness.  A bit drying from the yeast with funky, musky brett tones.  Mostly brett flavor and not tartness or anything like that.

Bottle (Batch 1 Oct 2011). From my bottles description on the back, this seems to be a DFH collaboration (description and signature from Sam). I think this one needs a bit more time (havent said that about any of the Anchorage beers yet). Pours with a lightly hazed golden hued body with a large and lasting, fluffy white head. Aromas are very floral, rose water, tangerine, watermelon, brett, white wine grapes, allspice and ginger. Some lemon peel and lightly earthy. Flavors show a lemony zest, mild acidity, medium to high alcohol, dry white wine, mild funk. Grassy. Also a young brett character (cheerios), that I havent seen in the other Anchorage beers. While I like the dry hop character, this cheerio character needs to age out, and is very distracting for me. My main, if only knock to this beer. It is light in character, and seems to be nearly aged out. Very mild astringency as well that could be alcohol related. Lively bubbles, warming and dry with lively bubbles and a light body. While one of my least favorite Anchorage beers at the moment, this example just reaffirms my views that this brewery is the best new brewery (bar none) of 2011, and a serious player. Despite being mildly disappointed, this is still an amazingly stellar beer!

750 c&c from The Davis Beer Shoppe in Davis, CA. Well carbonated! Pours tarnished dark gold with a creamy/bubbly white head. Aroma is mixed - vinous, bretty, citrus, light stone fruit. Med body. Flavor is oak, vinous, bretty, citrus, bready, - and my sinus just exploded. Figuratively speaking. This is spicy stuff. Add spice to the flavor list.  Smooth, lightly sour and complex. Finishes dry, spicy and bretty.  Another brilliant ale from Anchorage.

750 ml. bottle from The Beer Mongers in Portland, Oregon. I was really enjoying this, while making dinner, so I decided to sit down and actually rate the fucking thing. Fluffy head, at first, and then it recedes to a nice thin and wispy head. This is sitting on top of a hazy gold/orange body. Looks pretty good to me. Lovely crisp brett aroma, with some oak, and wine, as well. Dough, and yeast seem to hit my olfactories. This isnt completely dominated by the brett, which a lot of their beers seem to be. This has a nice rich texture, at first, and then it things out, and dries up a bit. Slightly fruity, with oak, dough, yeast, sugar, and of course, brett. I like this twist on a Tripel. The brett is quite prickly at times. I really like this beer.

750ml bottle. Hazy golden orange with a small pure white head. Aroma of musty oak, candi sugar and some herbal tea. Flavor is semi-sweet sugary malt, wet wood, with just a touch of earthy, sour yeast, the alcohol is completely hidden. Medium body with mild carbonation and a smooth, soft mouth feel. This is a good beer but light sourness kind of takes away from the base beer in my opinion, I actually think I would like a none oak/brett version of this better.
